docs.lead_paragraph: The way stressful events affect the body may depend on whether those subjected to the stress can do anything to change the situation, a new study suggests. For an article published in the journal Psychophysiology, researchers from Ohio State University and the University of Amsterdam subjected 24 men in college to two very different experiences. In one, they were active participants; in the other, passive observers.

headline.main: Facing Up to the Helplessness Factor

docs.abstract: Study suggests that way stressful events affect body may depend on whether those subject to stress can do anything to change situation (S)
docs.snippet: The way stressful events affect the body may depend on whether those subjected to the stress can do anything to change the situation, a new study suggests.     For an article published in the journal Psychophysiology, researchers from Ohio State...

docs.lead_paragraph: The woman's hair was gone, her bare scalp hidden beneath a stretchy pink turban. Her head drooped; to converse, we crouched to meet her gaze. Her breasts had been removed some time ago. Her arms were swollen, hands almost useless. Peeking out from the neck of her gown were patches where her cancer had returned, a thick layer encasing her in a red leather corset. I stood amid other white coats on rounds, musing on my coming evening at the theater, half listening to the awkward exchange between the intern and the woman in the wheelchair. It was hard to see her except as too sickly to leave the hospital, hard to reconcile her appearance with her position as dean of students at a nearby college.
docs.abstract: Dr Kathleen M Ogle essay expresses concern that doctors, confronted with dying patients, are sometimes more interested in following professional protocols than in considering best interests, and wishes, of patient involved; recalls case in which dying patient was not permitted out to see a play, The Gospel at Colonus, that might have done her more good than her hospital confinement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Let's say you're a primary care physician with a large number of H.I.V.-infected patients. Until a few years ago, almost all your patients died; now, with new medications, many are doing great, and you know you're making a difference. There's just one small problem: your practice is going bankrupt. What do you do? If you're Dr. Jeff Goodgame, you fret about your patients, meet with financial advisers and wrestle with your conscience. Then you close up shop and accept a job as a manager in the research department at a drug company.

headline.main: H.I.V. Practices Face Grim Financial Times

docs.abstract: Growing number of doctors treating HIV-infected people are struggling to keep their practices afloat; blame managed care, particularly health maintenance organizations, which pay primary care physicians the same flat monthly fee for every patient, healthy or sick; many HIV patients receive all their treatment from primary care physicians and make relatively great demands on their time, sometimes for as little as $5 a month; one remedy would be to create category of HIV specialists, who would be entitled to higher reimbursements (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: If Air Force personnel are any indication, work rules about weight can act as a powerful force to keep smokers smoking, a new study suggests. The study, conducted by researchers at Brooks Air Force Base in Texas, was published this month in The American Journal of Health Promotion.

headline.main: Focus on Health, One Problem at a Time

docs.abstract: Active-duty Air Force personnel who are close to weight limits are found to be less likely to enroll in program for quitting smoking, fearing they might put on pounds if they quit; researchers suggest that military consider giving smokers waivers to weight rules to enable them to work on one health problem at a time (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In June, a panel of medical experts issued a stunning indictment of the care offered to cancer patients in America at the end of life. Many of the 550,000 patients who die of cancer each year spend their last days in distress, suffering from pain, nausea, fatigue and depression. Their families suffer along with them, said the report, by the National Cancer Policy Board of the Institute of Medicine and National Research Council. The report, ''Improving Palliative Care for Cancer,'' can be found at www.iom.edu.

headline.main: Pioneer in the Battle to Avert Needless Pain and Suffering

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Kathleen M Foley, founder of pain service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, on inadequacy of palliative care provided to people with cancer and other terminal illnesses; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Poor people who live into middle age tend to die of the same causes as their more affluent peers, but to die earlier, according to a new study in The British Medical Journal. The study identified the 70,365 surviving men and women in Scotland in 1974 who had been born there in 1920, and analyzed death and economic data about them until 1997, when they were 77.

headline.main: Rich and Poor: Same Ills, Different Clock

docs.lead_paragraph: Is waiting for people to fall ill the only way to detect the presence of anthrax spores? Or might small animals like guinea pigs be used as ''sentinels'' to provide an earlier warning? Some scientists say the idea of using animal sentinels is too impractical to consider seriously, but other scientists say the idea should be explored because the issue is so important.

headline.main: Anthrax Version of the Canary in the Coal Mine Is Suggested

docs.abstract: Some scientists suggest that small animals like guinea pigs be used as 'sentinels' to provide earlier warning of presence of anthrax spores; Dr Bruce G Weniger, epidemiologist at Centers for Disease Control, backs proposal; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Calcium supplements can help older people hang on to their teeth as well as keep their hips strong, according to a study published late last month in The American Journal of Medicine. The study followed 145 healthy people over the age of 65 who were being given calcium supplements and vitamin D as part of a research project on bone loss in the hip.

headline.main: Save a Hip Bone, Save a Tooth

docs.lead_paragraph: Some women with diseases related to immune system malfunctions find that their symptoms subside during pregnancy, then rebound after childbirth. A new study at the National Institutes of Health suggests that the cycle may be caused by steps the pregnant woman's body takes to regulate stress and protect the fetus from being rejected by the mother's body.
docs.abstract: Study finds that symptoms experienced by women with diseases related to immune system malfunctions subside during pregnancy and rebound after childbirth; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Giving blood transfusions to elderly heart attack patients who are anemic appears to reduce their death rates within the next month, according to a study published on Oct. 25 in The New England Journal of Medicine. The study, conducted at Yale, involved reviewing the records of 78,974 elderly heart patients. The researchers said they were surprised at how much anemia they found -- just over 40 percent of the patients had low red blood cell counts.

headline.main: A Simple Procedure for Extending Life
